content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # Filter down to only Audi cars
    df_audis = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi", df_cars)

    # Filter down to only A4 or A4 Quattro models
    df_a4s = filter(row -> (row[:model] == "A4" || row[:model] == "A4 quattro"), df_audis)

    # Create a new column called audi_a4_type and set all values to true
    df_a4s_with_flag = copy(df_a4s)
    addcolumn!(df_a4s_with_flag, :audi_a4_type, true)

    return df_a4s_with_flag
end

# Example usage:

# Generate sample data
n_cars = 10
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer = ["Audi", "BMW", "Toyota", "Audi", "VW", "Audi", "Honda", "Audi", "Audi", "Audi"],
                   model = ["A4", "320i", "Corolla", "A4 Quattro", "Golf", "A6", "Civic", "A4", "Q7", "A4"])

# Filter down to desired rows and add new column
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)

# Display the first 5 rows of the filtered DataFrame
head(filtered_df)
